Susan Ruddiman, The Mississippi Press
on February 24, 2012 at 11:40 AM, updated February 24, 2012 at 11:50 AM
'title':'Ocean Springs issues boil water notice for Magnolia Bayou Estates',

'desc': 'OCEAN SPRINGS, Mississippi - There is a boil water notice in effect throughout Magnolia Bayou Estates in Ocean Springs until further notice, announced Andre Kaufman, director of public works. ',
OCEAN SPRINGS, Mississippi - There is a boil water notice in effect throughout Magnolia Bayou Estates in Ocean Springs until further notice, announced Andre Kaufman, director of public works.
The water must be boiled as a result of a broken water main. Affected residents should vigorously boil their water for 1 minute before consumption.
Testing will be performed and a clear water notice will be issued when it is safe to drink, Kaufman said.
Call the Department of Public Works at 228-875-3955 between 6:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. for details.

Boil water alert issued for areas of Pomona
POMONA -- The Rockland County Health Department has issued a boil water
order due to a water main break for areas of Pomona, specifically buildings
20 through 23, buildings 26 through 38 of the Pomona Park Condominiums
Buildings 20 through 23 and 26 through 30, the Pomona Park Clubhouse,
pool and recreation area are also affected.
Health department officials are directing all residents impacted by the
water main break to refrain from using the water for drinking or food
preparation without boiling for one minute first. Boiled water or bottled
water should be used for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth, washington
dishes and food preparation until further notice.

SAN LUIS — The disinfection of the town's water system started Thursday and may be finished by today at the earliest, state officials said.

Tyson Ingels, lead drinking water engineer with the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, said crews planned to fill the system's 300,000-gallon storage tank with chlorinated water then run it through the distribution pipes that serve 414 taps.

Routine sampling of the town's water supply came back positive for E. coli Wednesday, prompting a boiled water advisory for all of the town's residents.
<div class=""tnt-ads dfp-ad"" data-refreshable=""true"" id=""ad-1359718"" style=""min-height:250px; min-width:300px;"">

As of Thursday evening, there had been no reported illnesses from the contamination, according to the Costilla County Public Health Department.

Ingels said officials with the San Luis Water and Sanitation District checked their system for possible causes and found no smoking guns.

But he added that more testing was being done on the water system.

""More data will be needed to tell the whole story,"" he said.

In the meantime, a water distribution center had been set up at the town's fire station for people who have been unable to buy water.

Fire Chief Alfred Mondragon said 130 people came in to pick up supplies Wednesday and volunteers delivered water to 35 homes belonging to the elderly or handicapped who could not make it out.

Mondragon said officials were getting a pair of 1,500-gallon tanks to distribute water and expected them to be in place today.

As of midday Thursday the water distribution had been limited to a gallon per person, he said.

Still to be determined, is whether the water and sanitation district will have to chlorinate its water after this week.
<div class=""tnt-ads dfp-ad"" data-refreshable=""true"" id=""ad-1360219"" style=""min-height:250px; min-width:300px;"">

Ron Falco, manager of the state health department's drinking water program, said the positive test didn't automatically mean the district would lose its disinfection waiver.

But he said the district's waiver and the contamination would be up for a thorough review once the system is up and operating again.

The sanitation district, like six other distribution systems in the valley, delivers untreated groundwater to its customers.

""The ones with waivers have pretty long track records of not having a bacterial contamination,"" Falco said.

The San Luis district had only one other positive test for contamination, according to state electronic records dating back to 2002.

The system tested positive in October 2007 for total coliform — a species of bacteria that can indicate the presence of more danger parasites — but negative for E. coli. All repeat samples collected immediately thereafter also tested negatives.

Indiana American Water’s Terre Haute District  is issuing a precautionary boil water advisory for approximately 125customers in the Idle Creek Golf Community located on the city’s southeast side after water is restored to the area later this afternoon. Water service to the community will be shut down for approximately 4 hours beginning at 1 p.m. today to repair a leak on a 12” water main. Residents of the area had originally been notified the leak would be repaired beginning at midnight tonight, however, crews moved the timing for the work up after the leak worsened this morning.

The affected area includes all homes in the Idle Creek subdivision, the Dawg Leg restaurant and the golf course clubhouse and offices. Customers in the affected area are advised to drink and cook with tap water only after boiling it for approximately one minute. Tap water can be used for washing/bathing.

The Indiana Department of Environmental Management (IDEM) mandates precautionary boil advisories to ensure high-quality water in the event water pressure drops below 20 pounds per square inch (psi) in any part of a distribution system. According to company officials, boil advisories are issued as a precaution with a customer's best interests in mind. It's possible, but unlikely, bacteria could enter the water system when pressure in the line drops below 20 psi.

During the boil water advisory, the water company performs a series of tests to determine if the water meets regulatory drinking water standards. The boil advisory will expire at 7 p.m. on Friday, February 24 assuming sample results taken from several sites within the affected area show no bacterial contamination is present. Any additional information regarding this boil advisory will be shared with residents through local media outlets.
Customers can call the Indiana American Water Customer Service Center at 1-800-492-8373 for the latest updates.

Boil order to possibly lift Thursday afternoon
By STEVEN PENN, Times Staff Reporter

According to Brazil Water Superintendent Jake Raubach, a portion of the city is still under a boil order, but the water office should have more information Thursday after a sample taken today is tested.
""We conducted the second set of samples this morning,"" Raubach said ""I got done delivering the samples to the state board of health in Indianapolis around noon today.""
Raubach added he won't hear back with results until late afternoon Thursday, but at that time, he is optimistic the boil order will be lifted.
Raubach said the protocol calls for 24-hour back-to-back tests, and after testing on Tuesday, Wednesday's test is the last required.
The area was put under a boil order Monday, after a water line was damaged.

""The boil advisory is just for people from County Road 200 to 300 on the south side of State Road 340, and then everybody from CR 300 West, a little past 425,"" Raubach said Monday, ""so all those people on both sides of the road (are under a boil order).""
Raubach added Northview High School and North Clay Middle School are exempt from the boil order because both are on a separate line.
Raubach said the boil order stems from a line that was cut into by a resident doing personal work.

""(The person) had cut into a 4-inch water line that runs on the south side of 340,"" Raubach said. ""Somebody was doing some personal work out there, and we had to shut the line down (because) there are several people on that line out there, and we didn't feel comfortable not having a boil order.""
Raubach said his office has been working hard to lift the boil order.
""(We are) working toward getting (those affected) off the boil advisory,"" Raubach said. ""The men (who worked on the broken line) did a very good job, and had it back up pretty quick.""
The Brazil Times will continue to provide updates.

SAN LUIS - Residents here are being told to
boil their tap water after testing found E. coli bacteria

Wednesday.

The discovery set off a run on bottled water and forced the
cancellation of school in a familiar scene for a region that has

had three water contamination events in the last four years.

Costilla County Public Health Director Vivian Gallegos said there
had been no reports of any illness related to the contamination,

The contamination was discovered by routine monthly testing of the

San Luis Water and Sanitation District's supply.

The district supplies unchlorinated drinking water to the town of

629 from groundwater wells.

Tyson Ingels, lead drinking water engineer with the Colorado
Department of Public Health and Environment, said officials with
the sanitation district and the state health department would have
a conference call this morning to discuss a disinfection

plan.

Gallegos was directing a team of 40 people to fan out across the

town at dusk to post notices on homes.

The order calls for residents to use bottled water or bring their
tap water to a boil for at least three minutes before using it to

drink, prepare food, wash dishes or brush teeth.

E. coli is a grouping of bacteria that includes some strains that
can cause diarrhea, urinary tract infections, respiratory illness
and pneumonia, among other illnesses, according to the Centers for

Disease Control and Prevention.

The county urged residents or recent visitors to San Luis who
experience stomach problems to contact their health care

providers.

The boiled water orders are not unfamiliar in the San Luis Valley,
where many communities have drawn their drinking water from

groundwater supplies and distributed it without chlorination.

Monte Vista and Manassa faced state orders to chlorinate their
drinking water in 2010 after a string of positive tests for

coliform.

Alamosa also began chlorinating its system after a water-borne
Salmonella outbreak in 2008 resulted in one death and 122 confirmed

cases of illness.

News of Wednesday's contamination spread rapidly.

Mayor Teresa Medina was swamped with calls, many from residents in

the villages surrounding San Luis.

Those communities were not affected by the contamination and have a

separate water supply system.

The contamination also prompted a run on bottled water in the

town.

Herman Sisneros, a district training manager for Family Dollar,
drove to Monte Vista, Alamosa and Center to restock water after the
store had been emptied by midafternoon.
<div class=""tnt-ads dfp-ad"" data-refreshable=""true"" id=""ad-1360219"" style=""min-height:250px; min-width:300px;"">

R&R Market also had water as of 6 p.m.

Gallegos said the town of San Luis also had purchased bottled water

for the elderly or those unable to buy supplies.

That water was being handed out by volunteers going door-to-door
and also will be distributed at the fire station while supplies

last, Medina said.

The contamination also forced the school to release students early

and cancel classes and sports practices until further notice.

The town's three restaurants closed their doors, including the

Covered Wagon, which is owned by the mayor's family.

Medina said she anticipates her restaurant will be closed for a
couple of days but will have a meeting with health officials

today.

Ventero Open Press, which doubles as a coffee shop for many of the
town's residents, already had stocked up on water and planned to

open today.

""Tomorrow I'll just throw up a sign saying we're using bottled
water,"" said Jeremy Elliott, Ventero's administrator.
